title: R40521
content: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) is a federal statute that provides funding for special education and related services. It requires states to offer a free appropriate public education (FAPE) to children with disabilities, identify and evaluate them, create individual education programs (IEPs), and involve parents in planning and overseeing services. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) mandates individual education programs (IEPs) for children with disabilities, involving parents in planning and overseeing services. It ensures children with disabilities are educated alongside non-disabled peers and provides procedural safeguards, including the right to a due process hearing and appeal. IDEA was enacted in 1975 in response to the need for education for children with disabilities, with the most recent reauthorization in 2004. Congress is currently considering potential issues for the next reauthorization. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) mandates individual education programs (IEPs) for children with disabilities, involving parents in planning and overseeing services. The most recent reauthorization of IDEA was P.L. 108-446 in 2004, with specific authorizations for appropriations through 2011. Congress is currently identifying potential issues for the next reauthorization. The IDEA definition of a child with a disability is categorical, requiring special education and related services. The IDEA definition categorizes a child with a disability as one who needs special education and related services. In Hansen v. Republic R-III School District, the court determined that a child with conduct disorder, bipolar disorder, and ADHD qualified as a child with a disability under IDEA due to serious emotional disturbance and other health impairments affecting educational performance. The court found that a child with ADHD and educational struggles qualified as a child with a disability under IDEA. Court decisions have debated whether minimal educational impact still qualifies a child as disabled under IDEA, with one case ruling in favor of a child with Asperger's Syndrome. The court rejected the notion that IDEA is limited to children with significant educational impacts. The court rulings on children with disabilities under IDEA vary, with one case involving a child with high grades and intellectual ability being considered disabled despite minimal impact on educational performance. Another case involved a child with schizophrenia who was deemed disabled due to missed school, incomplete assignments, and potential relapse in a public school setting. However, a child with ADHD, depression, and other disorders was not eligible for IDEA services as her behavior did not significantly affect her educational performance. The Ninth Circuit ruled that a child with ADHD, depression, and other disorders was not eligible for IDEA services as her behavior did not adversely affect her educational performance. Other cases also found that children with various disorders did not meet the requirements for seriously emotionally disturbed under IDEA regulations. The Second Circuit found that a child, even if seriously emotionally disturbed, lacked evidence of adverse effects on educational performance. IDEA mandates states to have policies for identifying and evaluating children with disabilities needing special education, known as child find. In Compton Unified School District v. The Supreme Court is considering whether parents can file due process complaints for school officials' failure to provide an educational program for children with disabilities, as required by IDEA. The core requirement of IDEA is to provide children with disabilities a free appropriate public education to receive federal funding. The Court emphasized that the education provided to children with disabilities must confer some educational benefit and include specialized instruction and related services tailored to each child's needs.
